conclusion: Several identical small steel balls are released from a position on an inclined plane every 0.1 seconds without initial velocity.
A photograph shows some of these balls at different positions on the incline, labeled as A, B, and C.
The distances between A and B, and B and C are given: AB = 15 cm and BC = 20 cm.
The photograph has a 1:1 scale relationship with the actual object.
The task is to find the velocity of ball B.
Balls are released without initial velocity, starting from rest and accelerating down the incline due to gravity.
The time between releases is 0.1 seconds, meaning each subsequent ball starts moving 0.1 seconds after the previous one.
Balls A, B, and C are at different positions on the incline.
Assuming the photograph was taken at a certain time after the first ball was released, relate the positions of the balls to the time they've been moving.
Denote t as the time elapsed since the first ball was released.
Denote tn as the time elapsed since the nth ball was released.
Ball A was released at t=0, so it has been moving for t seconds.
Ball B was released at t=0.1 s, so it has been moving for t - 0.1 s.
Ball C was released at t=0.2 s, so it has been moving for t - 0.2 s.
For an object starting from rest and accelerating uniformly, the distance covered is given by s = 1/2 a t^2.
s is the distance, a is the acceleration, t is the time.
Denote the acceleration down the incline as a.
Position of Ball A: sa = 1/2 a t^2.
Position of Ball B: sb = 1/2 a (t - 0.1)^2.
Position of Ball C: sc = 1/2 a (t - 0.2)^2.
Given AB = 15 cm and BC = 20 cm, write sa - sb = 15 cm and sb - sc = 20 cm.
